required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

brief_summary.textblock:
There is currently no available data regarding using the inpatient setting as an opportunity to talk to parents/guardians about firearm safety. The investigators will be doing a pre-/post-intervention study to investigate the effect of an intervention (a 5.5 minute Be SMART video and written materials developed by the organization Everytown for Gun Safety), on parental/legal guardian knowledge, attitudes and practices regarding firearm safety. While the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends the safest home for children is one without guns, the reality is that there are families with guns in the home. This non-political video focuses on ways to keep children safe from firearms.
The investigators will also investigate any additional effect of physician-delivered counseling on parental/guardian knowledge, attitudes and practices regarding gun safety as compared to receiving the information solely via video and written materials.
Participants will be randomized to 1 of 3 groups (intervention, intervention + MD discussion and control group). Outcomes will be assessed immediately post intervention and in a 30-day follow up phone call.

detailed_description.textblock:
Eligibility:
All parents/guardians of inpatients admitted to the Children's Hospital at Montefiore.
Exclusion:
Parents/guardians whose children are in acute distress or in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit.
Outcomes:
The primary outcome is the change in parent/legal guardian's behavior over the past 30 days with respect to how often they asked whether or not there are guns in the home when their child/children goes to play in another's person's home, as indicated by a Likert scale assignment of an ordinal value (1-5, 1= never, 2=rarely, 3=sometimes, 4=most of the time, 5=always).
Secondary outcomes will include:
- Change in the primary outcome (intention to ask noted above) between the intervention groups (Be SMARTalone vs. Be SMART + MD)
- Demographic factors associated with primary outcome
- Description of general knowledge on firearm safety of parents/legal guardians of patients in our community
- Description of attitudes about firearm safety of parents/legal guardians of patients in our community
- Description of general practices regarding firearm safety of parents/legal guardians of patients in our community
- Description of parents attitudes regarding physicians discussing firearm safety with them

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Likert Scale of Frequency of Asking About Guns in the Home When Their Child Goes to Another Person's Home, Pre-intervention and 1 Month Post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome is within each group the change in how often the parent/guardian asked whether there are guns in the home when the child went to another person's home in the last 30 days Likert Scale 1=never, 2=rarely, 3=sometimes, 4=most of the time, 5=always

secondary_outcome.measure: Doctors Who Take Care of Kids Should Talk to Parents About Safe Gun Storage at 1 Month Post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Likert Scale Score of degree of agreement with the statement 1=strongly disagree, 2=disagree, 3=not sure, 4=agree, 5=strongly agree

arm_group.description: Parents/guardians in this study group will watch a 5.5 minute Be SMART video and receive the handouts reviewing the information.

Parents/guardians in this study group will watch a 5.5 minute Be SMART video and receive the handouts reviewing the information and will also have an MD review the information (via a checklist to standardize the MD review).
Parents/guardians in this study group will watch a video "Kids and Smoke Don't Mix" and receive handouts reviewing information on tobacco smoke exposure (TSE).

intervention.description: An educational campaign that is non-political reviewing gun safety measures for preventing firearm injuries in children. There is both a video and written materials reviewing the information. The acronym SMART stands for: Secure all guns in your home, Model responsible behavior, Ask about unsecured guns in other homes, Recognize the risks of teen suicide, Tell your peers to be SMART
A video called "Kids and Smoke Don't Mix" and handouts on tobacco smoke exposure (TSE) developed by the New York state quit-line.

An educational campaign that is non-political reviewing gun safety measures for preventing firearm injuries in children. There is both a video and written materials reviewing the information. The acronym SMART stands for: Secure all guns in your home, Model responsible behavior, Ask about unsecured guns in other homes, Recognize the risks of teen suicide, Tell your peers to be SMART. After being presented to parents/guardians via video and handouts, this information will be reviewed in person with a Physician.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
-
Exclusion Criteria:
- parents/guardians whose child is hospitalized in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit
- parents/guardians whose child is in acute distress
- parents/guardians who have previously been in the study

overall_official.affiliation: Children's Hospital at Montefiore-Department of Pediatrics, Division of Hospital Medicine

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Pediatrics, Attending Physician Pediatric Hospital Medicine

patient_data.ipd_description: There is no plan to share individual participant data with other researchers. The data will only be available to study personnel approved on this study.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This study examine knowledge, attitudes, and practices of parents/legal guardians regarding firearm safety and tobacco smoke exposure. Children were not enrolled.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: The parent/guardian only was enrolled (child was not), therefore it is not a dyad.

group.title: Be SMART Alone
group.description: Parents/guardians in this study group will watch a 5.5 minute Be SMART video and receive the handouts reviewing the information. Be SMART: An educational campaign that is non-political reviewing gun safety measures for preventing firearm injuries in children. There is both a video and written materials reviewing the information. The acronym SMART stands for: Secure all guns in your home, Model responsible behavior, Ask about unsecured guns in other homes, Recognize the risks of teen suicide, Tell your peers to be SMART

group.title: Be SMART + MD Review
group.description: Parents/guardians in this study group will watch a 5.5 minute Be SMART video and receive the handouts reviewing the information and will also have an MD review the information (via a checklist to standardize the MD review). Be SMART + MD review: An educational campaign that is non-political reviewing gun safety measures for preventing firearm injuries in children. There is both a video and written materials reviewing the information. The acronym SMART stands for: Secure all guns in your home, Model responsible behavior, Ask about unsecured guns in other homes, Recognize the risks of teen suicide, Tell your peers to be SMART. After being presented to parents/guardians via video and handouts, this information will be reviewed in person with a Physician.

group.title: Control: TSE Materials
group.description: Parents/guardians in this study group will watch a video "Kids and Smoke Don't Mix" and receive handouts reviewing information on tobacco smoke exposure (TSE). Control: TSE: A video called "Kids and Smoke Don't Mix" and handouts on tobacco smoke exposure (TSE) developed by the New York state quit-line.

participants_list.participants: Of these 47, there were 25 paired samples for primary outcome
Of these 45, there were 27 paired samples for primary outcome
Of these 43, there were 20 paired samples for primary outcome

measure.title: Age
Sex: Female, Male
Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Child age (years), median (IQR)
Child gender
Parental education
Language
Insurance
Seen a person with a gun?
Heard gunshots in your neighborhood
Raised in a home with a gun?
Been threatened with a gun?
Been shot with a gun?
Have a friend/relative shot with a gun?
Friend or relative has a gun?
Child has seen a gun?
Child has touched a gun?
Discussed with child what to do if they find a gun?
Discussed with other children what do do if they find a gun?
Guns have been brought into your home by guests
Have a gun in your home
Worry your child would play with a gun if they find one
Child's doctor has ever talked about gun safety
For those who don't have a gun, you would feel safer if you had a gun
It is important to ask about guns in others' homes when your child goes there

outcome.title: Change in Likert Scale of Frequency of Asking About Guns in the Home When Their Child Goes to Another Person's Home, Pre-intervention and 1 Month Post-intervention
outcome.description: The primary outcome is within each group the change in how often the parent/guardian asked whether there are guns in the home when the child went to another person's home in the last 30 days Likert Scale 1=never, 2=rarely, 3=sometimes, 4=most of the time, 5=always
outcome.population: Limited sample for analysis to paired samples within each group (samples where we have responses from the same study subject pre and post)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Single center with particular "gun culture" may not be generalizable to other regions of the country. Limited paired sample follow-up, therefore may be underpowered.
